post1.title: Career Change: A 'Loss' or a 'Gain'? A Coach's Perspective
post1.excerpt: Exploring the complex emotions that come with making a significant professional shift.

paragraphs: When clients come to coaching considering a career change, they often focus on the 'gain' – a new title, more flexibility, or more meaningful work. This is the exciting part. But any change, even a positive one, involves a 'loss'.

What might be lost? Familiarity. A clear identity. The comfort of expertise. Financial stability. It's often the unacknowledged grief for these 'losses' that keeps us stuck, not the fear of the new 'gain'.
article.quote: A coaching space allows us to name these losses without judgement, to honour what was, so we can fully step into what's next.

sections.heading: Honouring what changes
paragraphs: Before racing ahead, we spend time naming what is ending. Sometimes that means acknowledging the friendships, routines, or status that came with the previous role.
By slowing down to notice these changes, we reduce the surprise when unexpected emotions surface later in the transition.

sections.heading: Designing the next chapter deliberately
paragraphs: Once the losses are seen, we begin to design the habits, conversations, and support structures that will carry you forward.
This is where a coach partners with you to clarify your values and to experiment with new possibilities in a safe way.

outro: So, the question isn't just 'What do I want to gain?'. It's also, 'What am I willing to let go of?' and 'How can I honour the transition?'

post2.title: On the UK Job Hunt: Reading Between the Lines
post2.excerpt: Understanding the unwritten rules of the UK job market for new immigrants.

paragraphs: Moving to the UK introduces new accents, weather patterns, and—surprisingly—new job-hunt etiquette. Many newcomers assume that strong credentials and a polished CV will speak for themselves, only to discover the hidden rules that shape every interaction.
Coaching conversations often begin with frustration: 'I've sent fifty applications with no reply.' Together we unpick what employers expect between the lines.

sections.heading: Reading job descriptions carefully
paragraphs: Words like 'self-starter' or 'comfortable with ambiguity' signal that examples of proactivity will matter more than listing duties.
Highlighting collaborative achievements and demonstrating curiosity about the organisation's mission can move an application from the general pile to the shortlist.

sections.heading: Conversations that continue after the interview
paragraphs: Following up with a short thank-you note feels unusual in some cultures, yet in the UK it reinforces interest and professionalism.
Small touches—referencing a topic from the conversation or sharing a relevant article—signal attentiveness and help you stand out.
list: Summarise what energised you during the discussion.
Connect the role to the organisation's broader goals.
Invite the interviewer to continue the conversation if helpful.

article.quote: Cross-cultural transitions are not about abandoning who you are, but expanding how you communicate your strengths.
outro: With practice, the job search becomes less about decoding mystery rules and more about sharing your story with clarity.
If you'd like a partner in that process, our coaching sessions create the space to rehearse, experiment, and build confidence.
